key_points: Islamic State in Khorasan (ISIS-K) has launched attacks on Taliban forces in Afghanistan using guerrilla tactics similar to those previously used by the Taliban.
A deadly attack on Kabul airport and a series of bomb blasts in Jalalabad by ISIS-K highlight the threat to stability despite Taliban control.
Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid minimizes the threat of ISIS-K, but Taliban commanders express concern over their tactics, especially the use of sticky bombs.
ISIS-K has suffered losses from both Taliban and U.S. forces since its peak around 2018, leading to a decline in its activities.
Taliban security forces report killing three ISIS-K members, indicating ongoing conflict between the two groups.
Some analysts and the UN believe the return of the Taliban to power may invigorate extremist groups like ISIS-K and al Qaeda.
ISIS-K's strength is estimated to be under 2,000 fighters, considerably fewer than the Taliban's forces.
ISIS-K recruits include former Taliban members and fighters from the Pakistani Taliban (TTP).
Financial and logistical support to ISIS-K from its parent organization in Syria is believed to have considerably reduced.
The UN report suggests internal divisions within the Taliban could lead to defections to ISIS-K, potentially bolstering its ranks.
spokespersons: Rohan Gunaratna (Professor of security studies, Nanyang Technological University)
